elements.title: Divestments and Disposal Transactions

data.value: On 18 November 2020, Downer entered into an agreement to sell its blasting services business (DBS) to Enaex S.A. for gross proceeds of $62.0 million. The transaction was completed on 1 March 2021 with net proceeds of $59.1 million and a net gain on disposal of $6.5 million.

On 15 December 2020, Downer agreed to sell its Western Australian open cut mining business to MACA Limited for gross proceeds of $175 million. The sale, completed on 1 February 2021, involved asset transfer and contract novation, an impairment of $20.2 million, net proceeds of $133.5 million received by 30 June 2021, and a pre-tax loss of $14.4 million recognized.

On 4 March 2021, Downer completed the transition of underground mining services at OZ Minerals’ Carrapateena mine to Byrnecut Australia. Equipment was transferred for $56 million (book value), with net proceeds of $59.6 million received and a net pre-tax loss of $4.8 million recognized.

During the year, Downer disposed of its Snowden Consulting business. The sale was completed on 15 July 2020 to Datamine for a net consideration of $7.5 million, with a net gain on disposal of $5.6 million recognized.
On 28 August 2020, the Mining division disposed of its 44% interest in RTL JV to Thiess for a gross consideration of $18.9 million, resulting in a gain on disposal of $10.7 million.

On 2 December 2020, Downer agreed to sell 70% of its Laundries business to Adamantem Capital for $139.6 million net of transaction costs. The sale, completed on 31 March 2021, led to Downer ceasing consolidation of the business and recognizing its remaining 30% interest as an equity accounted investment. data.value: The document outlines Downer’s remuneration policy as aligned with its business strategy. It emphasizes linking executive pay to both short-term and long-term performance and ensuring alignment with shareholder value.

elements.title: Executive Compensation – Fixed Remuneration & Short Term Incentive (STI) Plan

data.value: Fixed remuneration is the sum of salary and the direct cost of providing employee benefits, including superannuation, motor vehicles, car parking, living away from home expenses and fringe benefits tax. It is designed to retain proven performers and attract suitable external candidates. Remuneration is benchmarked against both direct competitors and a sector peer group. Market levels are regularly monitored but there is no contractual obligation to adjust levels. Notably, no adjustment has been made to the Managing Director’s remuneration since July 2012, except for a voluntary 50% reduction from 1 April 2020 to 30 June 2020 in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The funds saved, along with additional contributions from Directors and other executives, were used to establish a fund for financial assistance to employees in severe hardship.

The STI plan for 2022 includes several key features aimed at driving shareholder value over a 12‐month period. It involves immediate cash payment for 50% of the award and two deferred tranches of 25% each over the following two years, with performance metrics based on Group NPATA, divisional EBITA, Zero Harm, and people-related measures. An Individual Performance Modifier (IPM) is applied based on individual key performance indicators.

elements.title: Recognition and Measurement of Right-of-Use Assets

data.value: Right-of-use assets are initially measured at cost, which includes the initial measurement of the lease liability, lease payments made at or before the commencement date (net of any lease incentives), and any initial direct costs as well as estimated costs to dismantle, remove, or restore the underlying asset.
After initial recognition, the asset is measured at cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses, with adjustments made for any remeasurements of the lease liability.

The right-of-use asset is depreciated over the shorter of the lease term and the economic useful life of the underlying asset. If the lease transfers ownership or a purchase option is expected to be exercised, depreciation runs from the commencement date to the end of the asset’s useful life.

If the recoverable amount of a right-of-use asset falls below its carrying value, an impairment loss is recognized. Future increases in recoverable amount can adjust the carrying value, but only up to the asset’s amortized cost if no impairment had occurred.

Judgements involve determining the useful lives and lease terms, reassessments when the initially anticipated lease term changes, and evaluating the recoverable value of the asset, particularly in relation to cash-generating units.
